race.name: De Ronde Van Grampian
race.tagline: De Ronde Van Grampian. 50 miles of gravel through Oxford.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Michigan countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Michigan event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: De Ronde Van Grampian is a local event in Michigan—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Michigan countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Michigan gravel race. Worth it for Michigan/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Michigan—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Michigan races: Barry-Roubaix, Iceman Cometh.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Oxford has limited lodging options. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Oxford has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check De Ronde Van Grampian website

non_negotiables.why: Michigan rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Single venue at Upland Hills Farm with 7-8:30 AM packet pickup and Epic Timing keeps things streamlined. c0nsumer notes "marking was good" and "solid and well executed on a really great route." The strict no-trespassing policy on private Upland Hills sections shows serious land access management for future editions.

length.explanation: Jason D finished the 50-mile course in 2:54, targeting "under 3 hours... I really wanted 17 MPH and thought maybe a stretch was 18 MPH." At 2,942ft of gain over 50 miles, it's respectable weekend warrior territory but won't test endurance limits like longer gravel races. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Michael Green describes "fast singletrack and a tight uphill climb" in the final 1.5 miles, while Jason D noted "one sketchy section with a washout that was terrible." The mix of two-track start, Barr Road climb selection, and sandy Upland Hills finish keeps you honest without breaking bikes. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Barr Road creates the first major split where "the fireworks started," according to Michael Green, while Mike Adsit found the "rollers... really toasted my legs." Nearly 3,000 feet over 50 miles creates steady grinding work without brutal singular climbs. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 80°F and lows of 63°F, with a 52% chance of rain on any given day. Weather varies dramatically year to year - Mike Adsit faced "super humid, 91%" conditions in the inaugural 2022 race, while Jason D enjoyed an "absolutely perfect weather day" in 2023. Early August in Michigan means potential heat and humidity that can sap you on those rolling climbs. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Topping out at 1,250ft on Drahner Road means altitude is completely irrelevant. This is Michigan flat with some bumps - your biggest altitude concern is whether your Garmin bothers recording elevation changes this small. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The private Upland Hills terrain you can't scout beforehand creates race-day discovery, and hitting Oakland County's high point has local significance. Singletrack at Bald Mountain and views along Lake George beat pure road grinding. But ultimately you're riding Michigan gravel roads, not exploring uncharted territory - it's adventure with training wheels.

prestige.explanation: C0nsumer calls this "a new race, for sure" that's still building recognition beyond the Michigan Gravel Race Series. No prize purse and local winners like Mark Eelnurme tell you this isn't attracting destination-level talent or national attention.

race_quality.explanation: C0nsumer rated the execution "up there with the likes of BRX: solid and well executed on a really great route" with good marking and 99% gravel. On-site mechanical support from KLM Bike & Fitness and Red Shed Cycles shows professional rider support beyond basic timing.

experience.explanation: The exclusive access to Upland Hills private land that you can't pre-ride is cool - no trespassing allowed means race day surprises on sandy, hilly terrain. Hitting Oakland County's highest point at 1,250ft on Drahner Road gives you bragging rights for about five minutes. Post-race free beer while supplies last and a Dutch windmill sighting won't save you from the reality that 50 miles and 2,942ft of gain is a Tuesday ride with timing chips. As Course Features puts it: "Natural rolling terrain in the area with amazing scenic views and a special single and double track mixed in for good fun! There is even a Dutch Windmill out on the 50 course!"

community.explanation: Solid Michigan Gravel Race Series event that brings together the local scene without pretense. Two bike shops providing mechanical support shows real community investment, not just race-day opportunism. The tribute nature to previous local races (Ronde van Stony, Grampian Challenge) means this has actual roots, not manufactured tradition.

field_depth.explanation: Results showing Mark Eelnurme and Kim Mapes as 2024 standouts indicate local competition levels. Michael Green won his group and age group while cracking top 30, suggesting decent participation but nothing indicating serious competitive depth beyond recreational riders. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Michael Green puts it: "The goal was to not get carried away and blow up on the first, decisive climb on Barr Road."

value.explanation: You get exclusive access to private Upland Hills terrain that's off-limits otherwise, 99% gravel roads, timing, mechanical support, and post-race food and beer. c0nsumer's comparison to "BRX" quality execution and three distance options from 12 to 50 miles make this solid bang for buck.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Michael Green's tire choice strategy - "higher volume 2.1 MTB tires on my gravel bike" - and Jason D riding a fat bike show equipment flexibility keeps gear costs reasonable. Oxford, Michigan location means modest lodging and travel costs unless you're flying in from far away. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
